awd_titl_txt: Conference: Zone of Convergence: Our Changing Planet
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists at Associated Universities incorporated (AUI) will host a collaborative, hands-on conference that will bring together researchers, educators, policy makers, indigenous and philosophical knowledge holders, to understand convergence science, and empower new collaborations in areas of global need, such as climate change. The conference will be multi-disciplinary in nature and will include topics in earth and space science, astronomy, and data science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Network for Earth-space Research, Education and Innovation with Data (NEREID) hosted a collaborative 2.5-day Summit that brought together researchers, educators, policy makers, indigenous and philosophical knowledge holders and others to explore solutions to society’s greatest challenges through interdisciplinary lenses and convergence science approaches. With the theme “Our Changing Planet”, participants explored various perspectives and approaches to help answer the question, “How can data from other planets beyond Earth help us better understand the planet we call home and how can a deeper understanding of planet Earth advance our knowledge of planets and the search for life in our solar system and elsewhere in the universe?”

Promotional materials for the summit emphasized the antidisciplinary nature of the conference as an opportunity to forge unanticipated new connections and collaborations while envisioning challenges and projects that can only be tackled by working outside of conventional disciplinary structures. While some traditional conference elements were included in the Summit, such as a first-day agenda, prepared lightning talks, and a keynote panel discussion, elements of an “unconference” were also selected to provide a participant-driven, collaborative, and informal forum for individuals with common interests or goals to come together, share knowledge, and engage in discussions. Unconferences are designed to promote open and spontaneous interaction among attendees, fostering a sense of community and innovation.

Day one of the Summit introduced participants to the unconference approach and opened wide-ranging discussions on convergence in science, data and education through presentations and a keynote panel. The day ended with a new installment of the very successful "NEREID: Convergence On Tap" series, designed to promote interdisciplinary dialogue and foster intellectual curiosity. The format of these sessions replicates the ambiance of a casual philosophical discussion in a pub, where participants can engage in open-ended debates or imaginative thought experiments while enjoying the convivial atmosphere. This “Convergence On Tap” activity focused on recently discovered exoplanets, encouraging attendees to think beyond the boundaries of their own expertise and into the broader realm of Earth-space and data sciences.

On day two, participants shared their ideas for new sessions and gave a short “pitch” to explain their topic. Participants self-organized into breakout rooms and were encouraged to let their interest and engagement guide them in and out of any room or conversation. Many of these “promising projects” were further developed throughout the day and even beyond the Summit.

An online, anonymous participant survey was distributed via email after the Summit. Results of the survey demonstrated alignment with the Summit's goals. In written comments, participants mentioned that they learned about the capacity for convergent thinking, indicating an increased understanding of convergence science. One hundred percent of survey respondents acknowledged that they formed new professional connections and/or collaborations outside their current professional networks that would not have been formed otherwise; All participants who were previously unaffiliated with NEREID have since become members. In addition, 80% of survey respondents were "Very Likely" to recommend the NEREID network to a friend or colleague, and the same percentage said they would attend another NEREID Summit.

For more information on NEREID, please visit https://www.earthspacenetwork.org/.
